channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report I-2024060038
item.description:
Report I-2024060038

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T00:40:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-15
  • City: BISHOPVILLE
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FLORIDA TRANSFORMER, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Due to force from acceleration or deceleration, a ratchet handle or a metal binder handle punctured the tote causing it to release its contents. The location of the puncture is thought to be about halfway up the tote. The duration of the release was along approximately 6 miles of highway. Emergency Response services were initiated, absorbent was applied to the roadway and traffic control was administered where needed. The trailer and any evidence of spillage was cleaned.

item.title: Report I-2024070092
item.description:
Report I-2024070092

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T00:40:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-14
  • City: LAKE ARIEL
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PENN TANK LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 132700
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: Driver made reversed hose connections to tractor mounted product pump. This caused the pump to draft from the receiving AST and into the transport trailer, ultimately overfilling the compartment, filling the vapor system, and releasing to the ground. The compartment dome lid was forced up due to pressure releasing larger amount until pump could be stopped. Product flowed by natura gravity to a retention pond adjacent to the AST delivery area. Lewis Environmental responded for remediation of ground and affected water retention pond.

item.title: Report I-2024070091
item.description:
Report I-2024070091

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T00:40:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-10
  • City: EPHRATA
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PENN TANK LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 11525
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Delivery driver failed to make proper hose connection to drop fitting. Driver opened delivery valve releasing approximately 10 gallons to concrete lot. Rainwater carried product into storm sewer. Product traveled through storm sewer to Cocalico Creek (1/4 mile away). Lewis Environmental reacted with containment booms in creek to contain. Booms remained in place to absorb any residual until no further evidence of product remained.

item.title: Report I-2024010059
item.description:
Report I-2024010059

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T00:40:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-01-05
  • City: Petersburg
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: RSI LEASING, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 1/5/24 at approximately 10:00 AM, Operators were loading ethanol from railcar MUI-X 730192 into Petroleum Carriers trailer 9301. While loading a scheduled 1400 gallons into compartment 2(capacity 2500 gallons), product. was released from the overflow tubes at the rear of the trailer. The pump 0meter read 1272 gallons at the time of the release. An estimated 100 gallons impacted the asphalt. Product evaporated, there is no cleanup material to be disposed of. All appropriate personnel were notified of the incident. Overfill protection on the pump was disabled by the loaders. Driver failed to advise loaders that there was product remaining in the compartment being loaded.

item.title: Report I-2024010046
item.description:
Report I-2024010046

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T00:40:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-28
  • City: Phoenix
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES GROUP INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A customer exited an aft Iavatory and handed an overheating vape that they had found in the Iavatory to a Flight Attendant. The vapewas making a clicking sound and was warm to the touch. The Flight Attendants placed the vape in a fire containment bag with water. The Captain was notified and the balance of the Flight was uneventful. Upon arrival, the Flight Attendants handed the fire containment bag with the vape to a Customer Service Manager at the Station.

item.title: Report I-2024010051
item.description:
Report I-2024010051

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T00:40:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-15
  • City: Los Angeles
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES GROUP INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Fifteen minutes after departing from BOS, the customer observed their crossbody bag that they were wearing smelled strongly of the e-cigarette juice. Upon opening the zipper compartment holding the e-cigarette he saw the blue light on and was unable to switch it off. The customer immediately notified a Flight Attendant to assist with the situation. The Purser obtained the e-cigarette and utilized the fire containment bag. The crew maintained custody of the containment bag until arrival in LAX when it was tendered to the CSM who met the flight.

item.title: Report I-2024010053
item.description:
Report I-2024010053

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-20T00:40:01+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-12
  • City: Charlotte
  • State: NC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: AMERICAN AIRLINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Passenger Drake Cox informed us of his laptop overheating inside of his backpack. When we got out the fire containment bag, he decided to bring the whole backpack to us. We put on the heat resistant gloves and a second Flight Attendant helped me with pouring a Iiter of water on the inside of the fire containment bag. I removed the laptop from the backpack and placed it in the fire containment bag with the battery facing down. The second Flight Attendant cleared out a galley cart and we placed the fire containment bag in the furthest aircraft right galley cart in the AFT of the aircraft. We continued to monitor the laptop throughout the rest of the flight, but no further action was needed. Once we arrived and all the passengers deplaned, the entire cart was brought to the forward galley as per the Supervisofs request and that's when the Supervisor told us Flight Attendants we were ok to leave and the rest would be taken care of. The laptop was an Apple MacBook Pro.

item.title: Report E-2024080373
item.description:
Report E-2024080373

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-13
  • City: CONLEY
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROADRUNNER TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On August 13, 2024, at 2050 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Roadrunner personnel in Conley, Georgia regarding the release of Socar Brake Wash (UN1208, Hexanes, 3, II). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 20 gallons of Socar Brake Wash (UN1208, Hexanes, 3, II) from (1) 55-gallon DM. The release was caused by a forklift puncture and impacted a 15ft x 20ft area of concrete on the dock floor. Contractors reported that the release had completely evaporated by the time they arrived. Contractors placed the damaged drum with the remaining product into a 65-gallon metal overpack then staged the waste onsite for proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024080369
item.description:
Report E-2024080369

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-12
  • City: EAST SAINT LOUIS
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: RANGER LANDSTAR INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On August 12, 2024, at 1321 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in East St. Louis, Illinois regarding the release of Eterset 2950 (UN1866, Resin Solution, 3, III). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 5 ounces of ETERSET 2950 from (1) 55-gallon DM that impacted a 5ft x 5ft area of the trailer floor. Contractors could not determine the cause of the release. Contractors placed the damaged drum with residual product in an overpack to be forwarded on to the original consignee, then cleaned the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste was containerized in (1) 5-gallon DF and taken offsite by contractors for proper disposal.

  • City: LOS ANGELES

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Package came out of trailer 830928 in a wet state. Package was placed in a tote for QA. Upon inspection, contents are 4 bottles of isopropyl alcohol, with 1 bottle having a loose cap, causing its liquid contents to spill out. No protection for caps or prevention from bottles from moving was the likely cause of the cap becoming loose. Better inner packing for both bottles and caps would help prevent caps from becoming loose.

  • City: DENVER
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: During sort operations at the DENR location a fiberboard box was found with signs of a release. While investigating the fiberboard box the spill agent found a plastic bucket and a plastic bottle inside. Packaged in plastic bags with packing paper for dunnage. The cap was loose of the plastic bottle causing it to spill all of the contents. The plastic bottle had a flammable liquid DG marking on it but no other labeling. There were no DG making or paperwork on the outside of the fiberboard box. All contents were placed into a steel salvage package and are being held at the location.

item.title: Report E-2024080384
item.description:
Report E-2024080384

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-05
  • City: WEST DES MOINES
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR INWAY, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 95000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On August 5, 2024, at 1631 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Des Moines, Iowa regarding the release of Lactic Acid (UN3265, 8, III). Contractors were dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up activities. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of Lactic Acid (UN3265, Corrosive Liquid, acidic, organic, n.o.s., 8, III) from (9) 275-gallon IBC plastic totes. The release was caused by a rollover accident and impacted the trailer floor, and an area of soil. Contractors placed neutralizer and absorbents on the soil in preparation for remedial and restorative activities, and the totes and trailer were transported to a nearby tow facility. At the tow facility there was an additional release of material that impacted a trail of concrete and the inside of a roll-off. Contractors neutralized, and cleaned all impacted areas with absorbents, then transferred the remaining product from the damaged totes into new totes. All waste was collected and containerized in (11) 55-gallon DFs and (9) 275-gallon IBC plastic totes, then staged onsite for proper disposal.

  • Description: E3OMI was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractors arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted two (2) 3ft-by-2ft area of the trailer floor and the concrete floor and estimated that one (1) gallon of material was released due to forklift damaging two (2) 5-gallon metal pails. E3OMI personnel deployed absorbent pads to recover the released material. E3OMI personnel placed the two (2) damaged pails into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum and the spent absorbent pads, impacted cardboard and PPE into one (1) additional 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

  • Description: Southwest Airlines F3204 departed Chicago Midway Airport(MDW) in route to Miami International Airport (MIA) but diverted to West Palm Beach Airport(PBI). On final decent into MIA about 25 minutes until landing when we experienced a fire and smoke on board froni a cell phone and power bank. Flight attendants used the on board fire containment bag and safety measures. Aircraft terminated in PBI and passengers were re-accommodated to MIA. Pictures available upon request. SWA FAA PHI David Evans and FAA Hazardous Material Aviation Safety Inspector Santos L Garcia have been provided pictures and information.

item.title: Report E-2024080429
item.description:
Report E-2024080429

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-02
  • City: GAFFNEY
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On August 2, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1760 was crushed in transit and released approximately thirty (30) gallons of product to the trailer interior, surrounding cargo asphalt, and nearby catch basin. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. A drum head vacuum was used to collect and containerize approximately 100 gallons of UN1760 impacted water from the catch basin of the storm drain into two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal. It was determined that the product remained contained to the catch basin and did not migrate or threaten to impact any waters of the state. Granular absorbents, absorbent pads, and neutralizer were used to remediate the impacted surfaces. The damaged drum was overpacked into one (1) 85 gallons drum for disposal purposes. All UN1760 impacted materials were collected and containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon drum for disposal purposes.

item.description:

  • City: LIVERPOOL

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 15000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 25, 2024, three (3) 55-gallon drums of UN2922 waste spilled in transit due to improper containment. As a result, the drums released approximately fifteen (15) gallons of product to the trailer interior, which further migrated to the parking lot below. Freehold Cartage retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Miller Environmental (ME) to remediate the impacted site. ME personnel utilized a vacuum pump to transfer product to a new 55-gallon poly drum. Crews worked to contain the release underneath and around the exterior of the trailer. ME personnel secured the site and scheduled to return at a later date for additional remedial operations. On July 26, 2024, a crew from ME returned to the site for additional remediation. ME personnel utilized a pallet jack to transfer the undamaged freight to the trailer for normal transport. All UN2922 impacted material was collected and containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LWA experienced a UN1789 Blue Whale Muriatic Acid release. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 4-gallons of product released to a 4' x 4' area of the trailer floor and a 4' x 4' area of concrete underneath the trailer. The release was caused due to the pallet collapsing possibly as a result of stacking. The impacted boxes and jugs were removed from the pallet. The impacted areas were then cleaned with absorbents and sodium bicarbonate. All impacted absorbents, debris, and damaged containers were collected into (2) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report I-2024080001
item.description:
Report I-2024080001

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-19T21:12:43+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-03
  • City: Greenville
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: federal express corporation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Bulk Truck#205997 was put on door. There was a foul odor coming from the vehicle which smelled like vinegar. The bulk truck was pulled off the door and parked in the yard with the back door left open in order to air it out. Later during the sort, the bulk truck was put back on door however the odor did not dissipate. Once some packages were pulled out, the spill was evident. Blue dye was all over the floor on the right side of the vehicle. A(formerly) white pail was on its side with the top cap open. The pail was covered in blue dye which covered the label and any other information. We started pulling out the leaked-on packages and came across a second white pail which was identical to the first and listed as 1 of 2. Upon inspection, a Corrosive Class 8 diamond label was discovered on the side of the pail. There were SDS sheets attached to the pail. Also on the pail was a manufacturing label which listed UN#, DOT shipping name of material, Technical name, Hazardous Class and Packing Group. No Hazardous Materials Certification Form was submitted, no OP-900LL on the pail and there was no"HAZ" marking on the FXG shipping label. The shipper shipped this as an Undeclared Hazmat(TRACKING#777176962630). This shipment was classified as a PGI. Since we were dealing with a high danger hazmat and all 6 gallons had spilled out, it was determined that any intemal attempt at cleanup was beyond our capabilities and this incident needed to be reported. My first call was to the Emergency Spill number listed on the container which is required of the shipper. The company listed was CHEMTREC 1-800-424-9300. I filed a spill incident report with them and received a report number(#224070300268). They then instructed me to contact our company's Emergency Spill Response Service. The spill met the criteria listed for our FXG Emergency Spill Response Service 1-833-394-7745. Once contacted, I provided them with all the information that they required, and they assigned Alert#212661 to our request for assistance. They dispatched a cleanup team and instructed me to meet them when they arrived as well as remain on site during the cleanup process.

item.title: Report I-2024070114

  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 24, 2024 a Tradebe Transportation driver made a customer pickup at the customer's location: Chem Processing INC, 3910 Linden Oaks Drive, Rockford, IL. After the driver returned to Tradebe Treatment and Recycling at 4343 Kennedy Avenue, East Chicago, IN the receiving supervisor noted that one of the totes was empty and that 200-250 gallons of material in the tote was released, It was determined that the material loaded in behind the tote shifted in transit and damaged the bottom valve causing the material to spill. The overall root cause was that the load was not blocked and braced properly.

item.title: Report I-2024070093
item.description:

  • City: SHEPHERDSVILLE
  • State: KY

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 34486
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver arrived at delivery site to pump product into the above ground tank. When the tank filled to capacity the 90% shut off didn't work and allowed product to overfill into diked area. Driver immediately called dispatch office, dispatch called headquarters and spoke to Julie Jennings who then called Perdue Environmental Contracting Company, Inc. for Emergency Response and Clean-up. Call was placed to NRC and KYEPA to report the spill and clean-up efforts.

  • Description: On 8/8/2024 at approximatley 1900, Dangerous Goods Adminstration received a call from Employee 3646681 at the ramp facility in Miami, reporting a hazardous spill. The shipment consisted of 4 fiberboard boxes, each containing two metal jerricans of fuel oil. One of the 4 boxes showed signes of spillage and emitted an odor. Further investigation revealed that one of the metal jerricans appeared crushed, most likely the cause of the spillage. The damaged piece from the shipment was placed in a salvage drum and the remaining pieces await and amended shipper's declaration for further transport.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 4500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics Terminal LBY experienced a UN1903 FMB 1210-8 Quat release from a 50-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released to a 1' x 10' area of the trailer floor and a 2' x 2' area of the concrete dock. The release was believed to be caused by a pallet nail puncture. The damaged drum was placed into an 85-gallon poly overpack. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The impacted absorbents and debris were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED USING ACCOUNT NUMBER 2A0Y40, CROWD COW, 120 MONAHAN AVE, DUNMORE PA 18512-1720.

  • Description: There was no product release, but a gassing or fuming from the mixing of the 2 products The Hawkins driver was instructed by Great Wolf Lodge personnel to deliver/pump the product in to the designated tank. Being a newly installed tank, it was not marked with the specific intended product, the driver proceeded to pump the sulfuric acid into to the tank not knowing that their was sodium hypochlorite in the tank. The mixture then fumed/gassed off leading to the evacuation of the area.

  • Description: On July 31, 2024, at 2226 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Dayton Freight Lines personnel in Byron Center, Michigan regarding the release of Ammonium Nitrate (UN1477 Ammonium Nitrate, Potassium Nitrate, 5.1, II). Terminal personnel reported that 1 ounce was released from (1) 10lb plastic bag due to a forklift puncture and impacted the dock floor. Terminal personnel cleaned the release and staged the 5 gallon DF of waste onsite pending disposal.

  • Description: On July 26, 2024, one (1) 100-pound pail of UN2800 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately one (1) pound of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. The crew overpacked the damaged pail into one (1) 55-gallon drum. HES personnel utilized hand tools to collect and containerize all UN2880 in one (1) additional 55-gallon drum.

R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site.   • Incident Date: 2024-07-19
  • City: DES PLAINES
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 19, 2024, at 0938 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Dayton Freight Lines personnel in Des Plaines, Illinois regarding the release of PERMAFIL 74035 (UN3082, Environmentally hazardous substance, liquid, n.o.s, 9, III). Contractors were dispatched and upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release of 55 gallons from (1) 55-gallon metal drum due to a forklift puncture. The release impacted a 8ft x 20ft area of the trailer floor, and a 5ft x 10ft area of concrete. The damaged drum was placed in a 85-gallon overpack and contractors were able to clean the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. All waste generated was containerized in (2) 55-gallon DM's, and (1) 85-gallon DM which was then staged onsite by contractors for proper disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070291
item.description:
Report E-2024070291

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-14T15:13:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-10
  • City: MANVILLE
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 2000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 7/10/2024 at 09:45 hours, DOT Inspector Alan Fisher was conducting an inspection at the CSX Manville Yard in Manville, NJ. Mr. Fisher reported a suspect release from the top of NATX301283, a loaded tank car of Acetone. CSX isolated the car and notified the shipper, Sabic Innovative Plastics, via CHEMTREC (Report #2024-0710-00165). Marion Environmental Inc. (MEI), a CSX emergency response contractor, responded to inspect the car. MEI personnel verified a release of product vapor due to a blind flange on the pressure plate have no gasket installed. Contractor personnel installed a gasket between blind flange and pressure plate; secured the nuts to stop the release. The condition found and corrective measure were communicated to the shippers representative (Skyler Davis, 812-781-4454). Following the emergency repairs outlined, the car was held pending bubble leak test by a certified mobile repair unit.

item.title: Report E-2024070779
item.description:
Report E-2024070779

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-14T15:13:37+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-10
  • City: Russell
  • State: KY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX TRANSPORTATION, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 15000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 07/10/2024, at 0541hrs., personnel in the CSXT Russell Yard discovered SIRX23534, a loaded tank car of Elevated Temperature, Liquid N.O.S. (Asphalt), leaking from under the jacket at the B-end brake support bracket onto the break assembly. The car was isolated and the shipper, Marathon Petroleum, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report #2024-0710-0049). Quick Response, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found product had leaked from under the jacket onto the brake assembly support but turned viscous as it cooled down and was malleable but solid. Subsequent investigation determined that the product released from the car due to a crack in the tank shell. The car was held out of transportation pending further investigation and observation by the owner and FRA, and pending a procedure to safely unload the car.

item.title: Report X-2024080676
item.description:
Report X-2024080676

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-13T15:14:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-06
  • City: LEWISTON
  • State: ME
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: The package was discovered while offloading the first inbound trailer of the day during the start of pre-load sort at around 3:15am wet/leaking. The package was then placed into a line bin & brought to QA for processing. Upon inspecting the packages exterior, the shipping label had a "No-Air" marking underneath the ground symbol, & and a slip that contained a Safety Data Sheet for the contents inside was found on one side of the box. It was also discovered that the package did not have any Hazmat/Hazmat paperwork &/or Limited Quantity markings on the package which raised some concerns. Upon opening the package 4 1-gallon cans of Seal For Life Industries Temper Kote 1000 41 Silver Industrial Heat Coating were found soiled & with the lids popped off causing them to leak contents. 3 out of 4 were also badly bent/dented & crushed on several areas of the can. None of the 4 cans had paint clips to help prevent the lids from popping off & no packing material was inside the package to protect the cans exteriors. According to Spidr image the package appeared to be unharmed when viewing overhead images of the package at MIDD hub, meaning the package may have loaded improperly & damaged in transit as a result. When referencing Section 14 under DOT classification in the Safety Data Sheet it was discovered the contents are classified as Packing Group 2 & as a Class 3 Flammable Liquid. Several packages were leaked on as a result of the spill but were able to be successfully repacked. The portion of the leftover cardboard from the repacks were held at the QA cage to be placed into the line salvage drum per cleanup. The Improper Shipping Form & Damaged Package Report were filled out. Contents & cardboard were placed into a line salvage drum & sealed. Large rubber green gloves & blue nitrile examination gloves were used when handing the hazardous material & an additional line bin was used as a precautionary measure.

item.title: Report X-2024080735
item.description:
Report X-2024080735

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-13T15:14:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-08-06
  • City: NEWARK
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At 8/3/2024 at approximately 2035, Dangerous Goods Adminstration received a call from Employee 301180 at the hub facility in Newark, reporting a flammable spill. The shipment cosisted of 1 plastic jerrican. The shipment was discovered to have been punctured on the bottom of the jerrican resulting in spillage. The cause of the damage appear to be human error. The drum was inverted to contain the spill and placed in a salvage drum, where it awaits an amended Shipper's declaration for further transport.

  • City: Mississauga
  • State:
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Description: On 8/3/2024 at approxiamtely 0745, Dangerous Goods Administration recieved a call from Employee 186946 at the ramp facility in Mississauga, reporting undeclared dangerous goods. The shipment consists of one cylinder packaged in a fiberboard box, which emitted a strong odor prompting further investigation. The accompanying safety data sheet identified the commodity as Diethylamine. The intensity of the lead to an evacuation of the 3rd floor of the warehouse. Canadian regulations required notifiying the Fire Department, who relocated the package away from the warehouse and further sealed the shipment. An outside vendor will assume final possession of the shipment for disposal.

item.title: Report I-2024070074
item.description:
Report I-2024070074

Identified by scraper @ 2024-08-13T15:14:07+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-05
  • City: West Plains
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VERNON WILSON TRUCKING INC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 25000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On June 5,2024, a Vernon Wilson Trucking tractor trailer was involved in a motor vehicle accident that resulted in a diesel fuel, motor, oil, and hazardous, UN1942 Ammonium Nitrate, 5.1, PG Ill release. To the roadway and soils. Approximately 100-200 gallons of diesel fuel and oil and approximately 5 tons of Ammonium Nitrate released to the soil. The Fire Department washed the diesel fuel and oil off the road to get traffic opened up. EWI indicated that there was 60' x 60' area of soil impacted by the cargo and a 60' x 150' area of the roadway impacted. EWI personnel applied absorbent materials to the roadway and will have to return to excavate the site. EWI personnel excavated the area and stockpiled it off the side of the roadway. On June 6,2024, EWI personnel returned to the site to finish the excavation. EWI personnel utilized heavy equipment to excavate the impacted soil approximately 1-2 feet in depth. Once the impacted material was removed, EWI personnel backfilled the area, spread to grade, and applied seed and straw. EWI generated(1) roll off approximately 6 tons of petroleum impacted soil and absorbents and(1) roll off approximately 8 tons of cargo and soil for waste.
